docs.lead_paragraph: Doctors sometimes joke that when children have surgery, their parents may need sedatives, too. ''Usually, high-anxiety parents have high-anxiety kids,'' said Dr. Shu-Ming Wang, an anesthesiologist at the Yale School of Medicine.
docs.abstract: Dr Shu-Ming Wang, Yale School of Medicine anesthesiologist, leads study on use of acupuncture on parents of children undergoing surgery to help ease anxiety; findings, which are to be presented at American Society of Anesthesiologists meeting, show mothers receiving treatment were less anxious and in turn made their children less anxious as well; drawing (S)
docs.snippet: Doctors sometimes joke that when children have surgery, their parents may need sedatives, too.    ''Usually, high-anxiety parents have high-anxiety kids,'' said Dr. Shu-Ming Wang, an anesthesiologist at the Yale School of Medicine.

docs.lead_paragraph: People with obstructive sleep apnea, a disorder that disrupts sleep, often suffer from acid reflux, a generally painful gastrointestinal disorder. But the relationship between the two ailments, if any, has remained murky. Yesterday, researchers reported on evidence suggesting that reflux may contribute to the sleep apnea. The findings were presented in Baltimore to the American College of Gastroenterology.
docs.abstract: Dr Brian P Mulhall, lead author of study at Walter Reed Army Medical Center, cites preliminary results that treating acid reflux condition in patients also suffering from sleep apnea may help reduce apnea; findings are presented to American College of Gastroenterology; drawing (S)
docs.snippet: People with obstructive sleep apnea, a disorder that disrupts sleep, often suffer from acid reflux, a generally painful gastrointestinal disorder.    But the relationship between the two ailments, if any, has remained murky. Yesterday, researchers...

docs.lead_paragraph: Use of a powerful but often neglected treatment for stroke increased sharply after an educational campaign was aimed at emergency care workers and the public, according to a study released yesterday. The treatment, known as clot-buster drugs, has been credited with helping tens of thousands of stroke patients avoid death or serious disability since it became available seven years ago, but many more people who need it do not receive it.
docs.abstract: Dr Lewis B Morgenstern, University of Texas Medical School (Houston) researcher, leads public awareness campaign about use of clot-buster drugs to treat stroke patients; study, published in Archives of Internal Medicine are focusing on three rural counties and five hospitals in eastern Texas, showed increase from only 14 percent of eligible stroke patients receiving treatment to 69 percent (S)
docs.snippet: Use of a powerful but often neglected treatment for stroke increased sharply after an educational campaign was aimed at emergency care workers and the public, according to a study released yesterday.    The treatment, known as clot-buster drugs, has...

docs.lead_paragraph: Kristy Sokoloski, 32, has chosen not to menstruate. After pain from endometriosis, in which pieces of the uterine lining become implanted outside the uterus, kept her bedridden for almost a year, she found a doctor who suggested that she take active birth control pills, nonstop, skipping the seven days of sugar pills and avoiding the monthly bleeding. After several false starts finding the right dosage, she now has about three periods a year.

headline.main: New Pill Fuels Debate Over Benefits of Fewer Periods

docs.abstract: Birth control pills, invented by Dr John Rock and originally developed around natural menstrual cycle, are now being used by some patients to suppress menstruation altogether; Seasonale, birth control pill that reduces bleeding to four times per year, has been approved by Food and Drug Administration and will begin distribution this month; critics of menstrual suppression contend that there are no long-term studies on effects of suppression; are concerned about risk of cervical cancer and fertility implications; Dr Leslie Miller, University of Washington associate professor of obstetrics and gynecology, discusses personal and professional experience with period suppression; photo (L)
docs.snippet: Kristy Sokoloski, 32, has chosen not to menstruate.    After pain from endometriosis, in which pieces of the uterine lining become implanted outside the uterus, kept her bedridden for almost a year, she found a doctor who suggested that she take...

docs.lead_paragraph: Seven years after New York State passed a law intended to make sure that insurance companies covered trips to the emergency room, researchers reported yesterday that many health maintenance organizations were still putting up roadblocks. In a study presented at a conference of the American College of Emergency Physicians in Boston, the researchers said that some H.M.O.'s violated the law and that many skirted its intent in an apparent effort to discourage patients from seeking emergency care. The report was presented by Dr. Charles L. Maddow of the University of Rochester.
docs.abstract: Dr Charles L Maddow of University of Rochester presents report to American College of Emergency Physicians concluding that seven-year-old New York State law, which was designed to make insurance companies cover emergency care, is not followed; drawing (S)
docs.snippet: Seven years after New York State passed a law intended to make sure that insurance companies covered trips to the emergency room, researchers reported yesterday that many health maintenance organizations were still putting up roadblocks.    In a...

docs.lead_paragraph: Zackie Achmat has always been a fighter. In 1976, as a young teenager, he was at the forefront of student uprisings against apartheid. He has been shunned in his extended family in a Muslim community for being open about his homosexuality and has been active in helping to secure a nondiscrimination clause for gays in the South African constitution of 1996. For the last few years he and his organization, the Treatment Action Campaign, fought the South African government to make drug therapies accessible to people with AIDS who rely on public health care.

headline.main: Never a Lull in a South African's AIDS Battles

docs.abstract: South African Zackie Achmat receives 2003 Nelson Mandela Award for Health and Human Rights on behalf of Treatment Action Campaign; although HIV positive and dealing with AIDS-related illnesses, he chose to go without therapy until South African government agreed to begin antiretroviral treatments for people who rely on public health care; United Nations population report lists South Africa as one of 7 African countries with HIV rates of more than 20 percent; photo (M)
docs.snippet: Zackie Achmat has always been a fighter. In 1976, as a young teenager, he was at the forefront of student uprisings against apartheid. He has been shunned in his extended family in a Muslim community for being open about his homosexuality and has...

docs.lead_paragraph: ''The Cardiovascular Cure: How to Strengthen Your Self-Defense Against Heart Attack and Stroke,'' by Dr. John P. Cooke and Judith Zimmer. Broadway Books, $25 ''There is magic within us,'' the authors of this self-help book begin. The magic they speak of is inside the 100,000 blood vessels that run through the human body, and it comes in the shape of a molecule, ''one of the simplest found in nature.'' The molecule is nitric oxide, ''a substance so powerful that it can actually protect you from heart attack and stroke.''
docs.abstract: Dr John P Cooke and Judith Zimmer, authors of book The Cardiovascular Cure: How to Strengthen Your Self-Defense Against Heart Attack and Stroke, discuss importance of nitric oxide, which is produced in endothelium, in improving cardiovascular health; photo (S)

docs.lead_paragraph: A vivid reminder of how tuberculosis plagued New York City in the early 20th century can be found on Staten Island. On display at the little-known Sea View Health Care Museum, on the former grounds of Sea View Tuberculosis Hospital, are a pair of mottled lungs from an 18-month-old who died from the disease.

headline.main: Once Upon a Time, a Plague Was Vanquished

docs.abstract: Former grounds of Sea View Tuberculosis Hospital (Staten Island, NYC) lend insight into disease that was once leading killer of people in New York City; facility, which houses Sea View Health Care Museum, is awaiting conversion of some buildings to housing for elderly; Tom Matteo, chief operating officer, explains hospital's contribution to cure for tuberculosis through development and introduction of drug isoniazid in 1951, grounds described; photos (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: ''Soothe Your Nerves: The Black Woman's Guide to Understanding and Overcoming Anxiety, Panic and Fear,'' by Dr. Angela Neal-Barnett. Fireside Books, $12. In the minds of many blacks and whites, according to the psychologist-author of this guidebook, a weak black woman simply does not exist.
docs.abstract: Dr Angela Neal-Barnett's book Soothe Your Nerves: The Black Woman's Guide to Understanding and Overcoming Anxiety, Panic and Fear explores ways strong black women can live healthier, more stress-free lives; photo (S)
docs.snippet: ''Soothe Your Nerves: The Black Woman's Guide to Understanding and Overcoming Anxiety, Panic and Fear,'' by Dr. Angela Neal-Barnett. Fireside Books, $12.      In the minds of many blacks and whites, according to the psychologist-author of this...

docs.lead_paragraph: How to hit a boy when he is down: Buddy Lorentsen, a 12-year-old from Patchogue, N.Y., loves soccer and wants to play on his school team. But he had cancer as a toddler and, as a result, he has only one kidney. His doctors and parents agreed he could play. But the school district said no: a child with only one of a pair of vulnerable organs could not play a contact sport. His family took the matter to court, and on Thursday a State Supreme Court justice ruled that Buddy could play. But his school, Seneca Junior High in Holbrook, said Buddy could not play until he had participated in 10 practices, leaving little of the season for him to play.

headline.main: A Pregame Ritual: Doctors Averting Disasters

docs.abstract: Jane E Brody Personal Health column examines importance of medically pre-qualifying students for athletic competition; pitfalls in medical evaluations discussed; 12-year-old Buddy Lorensten and his personal quest to play on school sports team outlined; importance of family and personal history in determining potential health issues for participants given; photo (M)
